canonical_explanation.text: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Robert Hooke first observed cells in 1665 using a simple microscope to examine a thin slice of cork. All organisms are made up of cells — some are unicellular (single-celled) like Amoeba and Paramecium, while others are multicellular (many-celled) like humans and plants. A typical cell consists of a cell membrane (plasma membrane) that encloses the cytoplasm and the nucleus. The nucleus contains chromosomes made of DNA, which carry genes — the units of inheritance. Plant cells have a cell wall outside the cell membrane and large central vacuoles, while animal cells lack a cell wall and have smaller vacuoles. Important cell organelles include mitochondria (energy production), chloroplasts (photosynthesis in plant cells), endoplasmic reticulum (protein and lipid synthesis), and Golgi apparatus (packaging and transport). In multicellular organisms, cells are organized into tissues, organs, organ systems, and finally the complete organism.
rules: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 by observing a thin slice of cork.
The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of life.
Unicellular organisms (e.g., Amoeba, Paramecium) have a single cell that performs all life functions.
Multicellular organisms have many cells organised into tissues, organs, and organ systems.
Cell membrane (plasma membrane) is a thin, selectively permeable boundary of the cell.
Cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance between the cell membrane and nucleus that contains organelles.
Nucleus is the control centre of the cell, containing chromosomes with DNA and genes.
Plant cells have a cell wall (made of cellulose) outside the cell membrane; animal cells do not.
Plant cells have large central vacuoles; animal cells have small or no vacuoles.
Mitochondria are the 'powerhouses' of the cell, producing energy (ATP).
Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll for photosynthesis; found only in plant cells.
Genes on chromosomes carry hereditary information from parent to offspring.

questions.question_text: Who discovered cells for the first time?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665. He observed a thin slice of cork under a simple microscope and saw tiny box-like compartments, which he named 'cells' because they reminded him of small rooms in a monastery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robert Brown discovered the nucleus, not the cell. Leeuwenhoek discovered bacteria and protozoa. Pasteur worked on germ theory. Robert Hooke was the first to observe and name cells.

questions.question_text: The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. All life processes occur at the cellular level, and every organism is made up of one or more cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atoms are the basic units of matter, not life. Tissues are groups of similar cells. Organs are made of tissues. The cell is specifically recognised as the basic unit of life.

questions.question_text: Robert Hooke observed cells in a thin slice of:
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke observed cells in a thin slice of cork, which is the bark of a tree. The dead cells of cork appeared as tiny, empty, box-like compartments under his microscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While onion peel, skin, and leaves also contain cells, it was specifically a thin slice of cork that Robert Hooke examined when he first discovered and named cells in 1665.

questions.question_text: The cells that Robert Hooke observed in cork were actually dead cells. He could see only the cell walls because:

options.text: Cork cells are the largest cells
The living contents had dried up, leaving only the empty cell walls
Cork cells do not have cell walls
His microscope could only see walls

questions.explanation_correct: The cork cells Hooke observed were dead cells whose living contents (cytoplasm, nucleus) had dried up. Only the rigid cell walls remained, forming the box-like compartments he saw under the microscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cork cells are not the largest cells. They do have cell walls (which is what Hooke saw). The microscope was not the limitation. The cells were empty because cork is dead tissue where the living material has dried out.

questions.question_text: Which part of the cell is called the 'control centre'?
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is called the control centre of the cell because it contains the genetic material (DNA) in the form of chromosomes. The nucleus directs all the activities of the cell, including growth, reproduction, and metabolism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane is the boundary, cytoplasm is the medium for organelles, and vacuoles store substances. The nucleus controls cell activities by housing the DNA that provides instructions for all cellular functions.

questions.question_text: The jelly-like substance between the cell membrane and the nucleus is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance that fills the cell between the cell membrane and the nucleus. It contains various cell organelles like mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi apparatus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell sap is the fluid inside vacuoles. Nucleoplasm is the material inside the nucleus. Protoplasm refers to all the living material in the cell. Cytoplasm specifically refers to the material between the cell membrane and nucleus.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the 'powerhouse of the cell' because they produce energy in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) through cellular respiration. This energy is used for all cell activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chloroplasts are for photosynthesis. Golgi apparatus packages and transports materials. Endoplasmic reticulum helps in protein and lipid synthesis. Mitochondria are specifically responsible for energy production.

questions.question_text: Chromosomes are found in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Chromosomes are found inside the nucleus of a cell. They are thread-like structures made of DNA that carry genes, which are the units of heredity that transfer characteristics from parents to offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chromosomes are not found in the cytoplasm, cell membrane, or vacuole. They are specifically located within the nucleus, enclosed by the nuclear membrane.

questions.question_text: The cell membrane is called 'selectively permeable' because it:

options.text: Allows all substances to pass through
Does not allow any substance to pass through
Allows some substances to pass through while blocking others

questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is selectively permeable, meaning it allows certain molecules to pass through while preventing others. This selective transport is essential for maintaining the internal environment of the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the membrane allowed everything through (A) or nothing through (B), the cell could not function. It is not made of cellulose (that is the cell wall). The cell membrane selectively regulates what enters and exits the cell.

questions.question_text: Which organelle contains chlorophyll and is responsible for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts are the organelles that contain the green pigment chlorophyll. They capture sunlight energy and use it to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen through photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria produce energy through respiration, not photosynthesis. Ribosomes make proteins. Lysosomes digest waste. Chloroplasts are the specific site of photosynthesis in plant cells.

questions.question_text: Genes are the units of inheritance carried on:
questions.explanation_correct: Genes are segments of DNA located on chromosomes within the nucleus. They carry hereditary information that determines the characteristics of an organism and are passed from parents to offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Genes are not found on the cell membrane, mitochondria, or cell wall. They are specifically located on chromosomes, which are made of DNA and housed inside the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is present in plant cells but absent in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell wall is present in plant cells but absent in animal cells. It is a rigid outer covering made of cellulose that provides shape, support, and protection to the plant cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell membrane, nucleus, and mitochondria are present in both plant and animal cells. The cell wall is the distinguishing feature that is found only in plant cells (and some bacteria and fungi).

questions.question_text: Compared to animal cells, plant cells have:
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells typically have one or more large central vacuoles that can occupy up to 90% of the cell volume. They store cell sap, maintain turgor pressure, and help in water regulation. Animal cells have smaller or no prominent vacuoles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plant cells have large vacuoles, not smaller or no vacuoles. Animal cells are the ones with smaller vacuoles. Both cell types have mitochondria. The large central vacuole is a distinctive feature of plant cells.

questions.question_text: A student observes a cell under a microscope and notices it has a cell wall, large central vacuole, and chloroplasts. This cell is most likely from a:
questions.explanation_correct: A cell with a cell wall, large central vacuole, and chloroplasts is a plant cell, specifically from a green part of the plant like a leaf. Animal cells (human cheek, muscle, blood) do not have cell walls or chloroplasts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Human cheek cells, muscle tissue, and blood cells are animal cells that lack cell walls and chloroplasts. The presence of all three features — cell wall, large vacuole, and chloroplasts — confirms it is a plant cell from a leaf.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is common to both plant and animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is present in both plant and animal cells. It is the outermost boundary in animal cells and lies just inside the cell wall in plant cells. It controls the entry and exit of substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell wall and chloroplasts are found only in plant cells. Large central vacuoles are characteristic of plant cells. The cell membrane is the common feature that forms the boundary of all living cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct difference between plant and animal cells?

options.text: Plant cells have a nucleus; animal cells do not
Animal cells have a cell wall; plant cells do not
Plant cells have chloroplasts; animal cells do not
Animal cells have mitochondria; plant cells do not

questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have chloroplasts for photosynthesis, while animal cells do not. Both have a nucleus and mitochondria. Plant cells have a cell wall, not animal cells. So option C is the correct difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both plant and animal cells have a nucleus and mitochondria. Animal cells do not have a cell wall (plant cells do). The correct distinguishing feature in this list is chloroplasts, found only in plant cells.

questions.question_text: An organism that consists of a single cell is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An organism that consists of a single cell is called unicellular. The prefix 'uni' means one. Examples include Amoeba, Paramecium, and bacteria. The single cell performs all life functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multicellular means many cells. Acellular means without cells. Colonial organisms form groups of cells. Unicellular specifically means made of a single cell.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a unicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Paramecium is a unicellular organism — a single-celled protozoan that lives in water. Dogs, rose plants, and mushrooms are all multicellular organisms made of many cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dogs, rose plants, and mushrooms are all multicellular organisms. Paramecium is a well-known unicellular organism that performs all life functions within a single cell.

questions.question_text: The correct order of organisation in multicellular organisms from simplest to most complex is:

options.text: Organ → Tissue → Cell → Organ system → Organism
Cell → Tissue → Organ → Organ system → Organism
Tissue → Cell → Organ → Organism → Organ system
Cell → Organ → Tissue → Organ system → Organism

questions.explanation_correct: The correct hierarchy is: Cell (basic unit) → Tissue (group of similar cells) → Organ (group of tissues) → Organ system (group of organs working together) → Organism (complete living being).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The organisation must go from simplest to most complex: cells combine to form tissues, tissues form organs, organs form organ systems, and organ systems make up the complete organism.

questions.question_text: Amoeba obtains food using temporary finger-like extensions called:
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba uses pseudopodia (meaning 'false feet') — temporary finger-like projections of the cell membrane and cytoplasm — to capture food particles. This process is called phagocytosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cilia are hair-like structures used by Paramecium. Flagella are whip-like structures used by some bacteria. Tentacles are found in animals like jellyfish. Pseudopodia are the unique extensions used by Amoeba.

questions.question_text: In a unicellular organism, a single cell performs:

options.text: All life functions: nutrition, respiration, excretion, and reproduction

questions.explanation_correct: In a unicellular organism like Amoeba, the single cell must perform all life functions including nutrition, respiration, excretion, reproduction, and movement. There is no division of labour among different cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A unicellular organism does not have different cells for different functions. Its single cell is responsible for all processes necessary for survival, from obtaining food to reproducing.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is responsible for packaging and transporting materials within the cell?
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus (also called Golgi body) is responsible for packaging materials synthesised in the cell and transporting them to their destinations, either within or outside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria produce energy. The nucleus controls cell activities. Chloroplasts perform photosynthesis. The Golgi apparatus specifically handles the packaging, modification, and transport of cellular products.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The cell is considered the structural unit of life.
Reason: All living organisms are made up of cells.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct, but reason is incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct and the reason explains the assertion. The cell is the structural unit of life precisely because all living organisms are built from cells — from the simplest bacteria to the most complex animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (cells are the structural unit) and the reason (all organisms are made of cells) directly explains why. Since every living thing is composed of cells, cells are the fundamental building blocks of life.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements about plant and animal cells is correct?
(i) Both have a cell membrane.
(ii) Both have a cell wall.
(iii) Both have a nucleus.
(iv) Both have chloroplasts.
questions.explanation_correct: Only statements (i) and (iii) are correct. Both plant and animal cells have a cell membrane and a nucleus. The cell wall and chloroplasts are found only in plant cells, not in animal cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Animal cells do not have a cell wall (ii) or chloroplasts (iv). These are exclusive to plant cells. Both cell types share common features like cell membrane, nucleus, cytoplasm, and mitochondria.

questions.question_text:
Match the organelle with its function:
(a) Mitochondria — (i) Photosynthesis
(b) Chloroplast — (ii) Packaging and transport
(c) Golgi apparatus — (iii) Energy production
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matches are: Mitochondria produce energy (iii), Chloroplasts perform photosynthesis (i), and Golgi apparatus packages and transports materials (ii).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria are the powerhouses for energy, not for photosynthesis or transport. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll for photosynthesis. Golgi apparatus handles packaging and distribution of cell products.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct comparison between unicellular and multicellular organisms?

options.text: Unicellular organisms are always larger than multicellular organisms
In multicellular organisms, different cells perform different functions (division of labour)
Unicellular organisms have more complex organ systems
Multicellular organisms have only one type of cell

questions.explanation_correct: In multicellular organisms, there is a division of labour — different types of cells are specialised for different functions (nerve cells for signals, muscle cells for movement, etc.). This is a key advantage over unicellular organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unicellular organisms are smaller, not larger. They do not have organ systems. Multicellular organisms have many different types of specialised cells, not just one type. Division of labour is the key feature of multicellularity.

questions.question_text: The nucleus of the cell was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Brown discovered the nucleus in 1831 while studying orchid cells under a microscope. He identified it as a central, dense body within the cell, which was later named the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robert Hooke discovered cells, not the nucleus. Gregor Mendel worked on genetics. Charles Darwin proposed the theory of evolution. Robert Brown is credited with discovering the nucleus.

questions.question_text: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in a cell helps in:
questions.explanation_correct: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a network of membranes in the cell that helps in manufacturing proteins (rough ER, with ribosomes) and lipids (smooth ER). It also helps in transport within the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria produce energy. The nucleus controls cell division. Chloroplasts perform photosynthesis. The ER specifically helps in the synthesis and transport of proteins and lipids.

questions.question_text: The cell wall of a plant cell is made up of:
questions.explanation_correct: The plant cell wall is primarily made up of cellulose, a complex carbohydrate. Cellulose provides rigidity and structural support to the cell, giving plant cells their characteristic rectangular shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell wall is not made of protein, lipid, or starch. Cellulose is a tough, fibrous carbohydrate that forms the structural framework of the plant cell wall, making it rigid and strong.

questions.question_text: A group of similar cells performing a specific function is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A tissue is a group of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function. For example, muscle tissue is made of muscle cells that contract to produce movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An organ is made up of different tissues. An organ system is made up of different organs. An organism is a complete living being. A tissue is specifically a group of similar cells with a common function.

questions.question_text: All living organisms are made up of cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. All living organisms, from the simplest bacteria to the most complex animals and plants, are made up of one or more cells. This is a fundamental principle of cell theory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. This is one of the key tenets of cell theory: all living things are composed of cells. Whether unicellular or multicellular, every organism has cells as its building blocks.

questions.question_text: Animal cells have a cell wall made of cellulose.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Only plant cells have a cell wall made of cellulose. Animal cells have only a cell membrane as their outer boundary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The cell wall is exclusive to plant cells (and some bacteria and fungi). Animal cells are bounded only by the cell membrane, which makes them flexible and able to change shape.

questions.question_text: The nucleus contains chromosomes that carry genetic information.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. The nucleus contains chromosomes, which are made of DNA. DNA carries genes — the hereditary information that determines the characteristics of an organism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Chromosomes inside the nucleus are composed of DNA molecules that encode all the genetic instructions needed for the cell's functioning and for passing traits to offspring.

questions.question_text: In multicellular organisms, all cells look the same and perform the same function.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. In multicellular organisms, cells are differentiated — they have different shapes, sizes, and functions. Nerve cells, blood cells, muscle cells, and bone cells all look different and perform specialised functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. One of the key features of multicellular organisms is cell specialisation. Different cells are adapted for different functions, which is called division of labour.

questions.question_text: Chloroplasts are present in both plant and animal cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Chloroplasts are present only in plant cells (and algae), not in animal cells. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll, which is needed for photosynthesis — a process that animals do not perform.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Animals obtain food by consuming other organisms and do not photosynthesize. Therefore, animal cells do not need or contain chloroplasts.

questions.question_text: Mitochondria are present in both plant and animal cells because both types of cells need energy.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Both plant and animal cells require energy for their activities. Mitochondria perform cellular respiration to produce ATP (energy) in both types of cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Even though plant cells can produce food through photosynthesis, they still need mitochondria to convert that food into usable energy (ATP) through cellular respiration.

questions.question_text: The cells that Robert Hooke observed in cork were living cells with all organelles.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The cells Robert Hooke observed were dead cells. Cork is dead tissue, and only the empty cell walls remained. The living contents (cytoplasm, nucleus, organelles) had dried up long ago.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Robert Hooke saw only the empty cell walls of dead cork cells. He did not observe living cells or organelles because cork is a dead plant tissue.

questions.question_text: The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. It is the smallest unit that can carry out all life processes independently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cell'. All living things are made of cells, making the cell the fundamental building block of life, as stated in cell theory.

questions.question_text: The organelle called the 'powerhouse of the cell' that produces energy is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the powerhouse of the cell because they are the site of cellular respiration, where glucose is broken down to produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate) — the energy currency of the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mitochondria'. These double-membraned organelles convert the chemical energy stored in food molecules into a form (ATP) that the cell can use for all its activities.

questions.question_text: The rigid outer layer of a plant cell made of cellulose is called the cell ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell wall is the rigid outer layer of a plant cell made of cellulose. It provides structural support, protection, and gives the plant cell its characteristic rectangular shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'wall'. The cell wall is distinct from the cell membrane — it is a rigid, outer structure made of cellulose that is unique to plant cells.

questions.question_text: Thread-like structures inside the nucleus that carry genes are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Chromosomes are thread-like structures found in the nucleus that carry genes. They are made of DNA and proteins, and carry the hereditary information from parents to offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'chromosomes'. These structures become visible during cell division and carry the genetic blueprint (genes) that determines all the characteristics of an organism.

questions.question_text: Organisms like Amoeba and Paramecium that are made up of a single cell are called ___ organisms.
questions.explanation_correct: Unicellular organisms are made up of a single cell that performs all life functions. Amoeba and Paramecium are classic examples of unicellular organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'unicellular'. The prefix 'uni' means one, and these organisms consist of only one cell that carries out all the processes needed for survival.

questions.question_text: The green pigment found in chloroplasts that is essential for photosynthesis is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in chloroplasts that captures sunlight energy for photosynthesis. It is responsible for the green colour of leaves and other plant parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'chlorophyll'. This pigment absorbs light energy (mainly red and blue wavelengths) and reflects green light, which is why plants appear green. Without chlorophyll, photosynthesis cannot occur.

questions.question_text: A group of similar cells performing a specific function forms a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A tissue is formed by a group of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function. Examples include muscle tissue, nerve tissue, and blood tissue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tissue'. Tissues are the next level of organisation above cells. Similar cells group together to form tissues, which then combine to form organs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms shows the simplest level of cellular organisation?
questions.explanation_correct: Bacteria are prokaryotic unicellular organisms with the simplest cellular organisation — they lack a well-defined nucleus and most membrane-bound organelles. Humans, frogs, and mango trees are complex multicellular organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humans, frogs, and mango trees are all complex multicellular organisms with specialised tissues and organs. Bacteria have the simplest organisation as they are single-celled without a defined nucleus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the vacuole is correct?

options.text: Vacuoles produce energy for the cell
Vacuoles store cell sap, water, and waste materials

questions.explanation_correct: Vacuoles are membrane-bound sacs in the cell that store cell sap (a mixture of water, salts, sugars, and other substances) and may also store waste products. In plant cells, the large central vacuole helps maintain turgor pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vacuoles do not produce energy (that is mitochondria), perform photosynthesis (that is chloroplasts), or contain chromosomes (that is the nucleus). Their primary role is storage.

questions.question_text: If you place a plant cell in concentrated salt solution, the cell will:

options.text: Shrink as water moves out by osmosis

questions.explanation_correct: When placed in a concentrated salt solution (hypertonic), water moves out of the plant cell by osmosis, causing the cell to shrink. The cell membrane pulls away from the cell wall in a process called plasmolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a concentrated solution, water moves from the cell (lower solute concentration) to the surroundings (higher solute concentration) by osmosis. This causes the cell to lose water and shrink, not swell or burst.

questions.question_text:
The cell theory states that:
(i) All living organisms are made of cells.
(ii) Cells are the basic units of life.
(iii) New cells arise from pre-existing cells.
Which statements are part of cell theory?
questions.explanation_correct: All three statements are part of cell theory. It states that all living organisms are composed of cells, cells are the basic structural and functional units of life, and all new cells arise from pre-existing cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell theory comprises all three principles: universality of cells in living organisms, cells as basic units of life, and the origin of new cells from existing ones. All three statements are fundamental tenets.

questions.question_text: The largest cell visible to the naked eye is:
questions.explanation_correct: The ostrich egg is the largest single cell visible to the naked eye. It can be up to 15 cm in diameter. While most cells are microscopic, the ostrich egg demonstrates that cell size can vary enormously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells and bacterial cells are microscopic. Nerve cells are long but thin. The ostrich egg is the largest known cell, easily visible without any magnification.

questions.question_text: A cell without a well-defined nucleus (no nuclear membrane) is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A prokaryotic cell lacks a well-defined nucleus — the genetic material is not enclosed within a nuclear membrane. Bacteria and blue-green algae are examples of prokaryotic organisms. Eukaryotic cells have a well-defined nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eukaryotic cells have a well-defined nucleus with a nuclear membrane. Dead cells are not a type of cell classification. Plant cells are eukaryotic. Prokaryotic cells specifically lack a membrane-bound nucleus.
